fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S \triangleright P be a container. A monad container (or mnd-container) on S \triangleright P is given by the following data: \begin {align*} \iota &: S\\ \sigma &: \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to S) \to S\\ \text {pr} &: \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to S\}} P\ (\sigma \ s\ f) \to \sum _{p : P\ s} P\ (f\ p) \end {align*} For which the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a ) &= a\\ \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) &= a\\ \sigma \ (\sigma \ a\ f)\ (\lambda p . g\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\ (\text {pr}_2\ p)) &= \sigma \ a\ (\lambda p . \sigma \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_1\ p) &= \text {pr}_1\ p\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) \end {align*} We abbreviate \pi _1 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_1 and \pi _2 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_2. The last three laws hold up to the "associativity" law for \sigma .

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad containers. It is cartesian iff P\ \iota \cong 1 and \text {pr} is an isomorphism. This is equivalent to saying that the extension of the monad container is a cartesian monad (container functors always preserve pullbacks).
These can also be seen as proper (1,\Sigma ) type universes (Tarski-style).
Here's a compilation of monad container examples for reference.

"Specific" monad containers:
Representable
Maybe
Writer
Coproduct
List
State
Reverse State - just a curiosity, only definable in a theory with unrestricted fixed points

TODO: Free

fr:title.text: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monad T is idempotent when T \eta = \eta T, which for monad containers immediately gives us \iota = s for all s : S, and hence S is contractible.

Another equivalent condition for a monad T to be idempotent is that \text {Id} is a distributive law TT \Rightarrow TT. For monad container distributive laws this implies futher that all positions are equal, so the set P\ \iota is subsingleton.

The extension of a monad container (S 	riangleright  P, \iota , \sigma , 	ext {pr}) is the Set monad on \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack  given by the data:
        egin {align*}       \eta _A &: A 	o  \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack \ A\       \eta _A\ a &:= (\iota  , \lambda  \_ . a)\       \       \mu _A &: \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack \ S 	riangleright  \lambda  (s , f) . \sum _{p : P\ s} P (f\ p) brack 
egthinspace brack \ A 	o  \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack \ A\       \mu _A\ ((s , f) , g) &:= (\sigma \ s\ f , g \circ  	ext {pr})     \end {align*}   
  The monad laws hold by the monad container laws on \iota , \sigma  and 	ext {pr}.

fr:title.text: There is only one representable monad container

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: There is only one representable monad container

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given the container 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . A, we look at the required data for a monad container. \iota and \sigma \ a\ b are trival (both are elements of 1). The equations for \text {pr} force it to be defined as the diagonal map: \text {pr}\ a := (a , a)

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad container. We call the monad container commutative when the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) &= \sigma \ b\ (\lambda \_ . a)\\ \text {pr}_1\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ p\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_1\ p \end {align*} The laws for \text {pr} hold given the first law. Commutative monad containers interpret exactly the commutative monads (w.r.t. cartesian product) for container functors.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as Set functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating all possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
Here's a compilation of monad container examples for reference.

"Specific" monad containers:
Representable
Maybe
Writer
Coproduct
List
State
Reverse State - just a curiosity, only definable in a theory with unrestricted fixed points
